characters: EXT. MANCHESTER ESSEX REGIONAL HIGH SCHOOL. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small commercial fishing boat heads out of Manchester, Massachusetts, toward the open sea. JOE CHANDLER, late 30 is in the wheelhouse. In the stern are LEE CHANDLER, Joe’ younger brother by five years, and Joe’s son PATRICK, abo years old. Lee and Patrick are kidding around in a friend way while Joe steers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a cold winter day on a narrow street. In front of a small apartment building, LEE sweeps away t old snow on the pavement, then sprinkles salt in front of building. He is 40 now, wearing janitor’s coveralls under weatherbeaten winter jacket. INT. BATHROOM. DAY. Lee works on a leaky toilet while MR MARTINEZ, 50s, a big in an undershirt and glasses, stands by watching.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARTINEZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know why the hell it keeps dripping. All night long, drip, drip. I’ve had the fucking thing repaired ten times.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You need a new stopper.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARTINEZ
dialogues.text: Oh is that it?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: See how it’s rotted around the edges? It doesn’t make a seal, so the water drips into the bowl. I can bring you a new one tomorrow, or you might want to consider replacing the whole apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ
dialogues.text: What do you recommend? Lee starts putting away his tools and cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I could replace the stopper first, and if that doesn’t work, then I would come back and replace the whole apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ
dialogues.text: But you don’t have a professional recommendation?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s really up to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ
dialogues.text: Well, tomorrow I got my sister-in- law coming over with my nephews .»+-and I gotta take my car in... Lee waits while Mr Martinez works out his schedule. INT. BASEMENT. DAY. He organizes the trash cans and recycling in the basement INT. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY. DAY. He vacuums the hall with an industrial vacuum cleaner on fifty foot yellow extension cord. EXT. QUINCY -- ANOTHER BUILDING. DAY. A different apartment building on a similar street. INT. MRS GROOM’S APARTMENT. DAY. Standing on a ladder in a small grandmotherly apartment, changes a light bulb in the very small bathroom. MRS GROO 70s, is on the phone outside the open bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GROOM
dialogues.text: (On the phone) No, it’s my sister Janine’s oldest girl’s bat mitzvah...No, I look forward to being bored to death... No, the girl doesn’t want it, the father doesn’t want it. I don’t ask. Seven hours in the car, I could really slit my throat...Oh, well, the little girls are charming.  EXT. QUINCY -- A SLIGHTLY MORE UPSCALE STREET. DUSK. A marginally more upscale building. INT. BATHROOM. DUSK. Lee looks down at a stopped-up toilet. Behind him is MARIANNE, slender, 30s, attractive, wearing everyday arou the-house clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. This is so gross.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s all right. He plunges her toilet carefully and methodically. LATER -- He wipes up the floor. Marianne comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh Lee, you don’t have to do that, honestly.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Well -- God. Thank you so much, I am so sorry. LATER -- He is washing his hands in her bathroom sink. He hears Marianne talking on the phone 0O.C.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, tell him to come! ... Okay, yeah ... But Cindy, I have to tell you something. I'm like, in love with my handyman. Is that sick? ... Have you ever had a sexual fantasy about your handyman? ... Well, it's awkward because he is literally like, cleaning the shit out of my toilet bowl right now. And I don't think I'm at my most alluring ... Yeah, maybe you're right. It's not like I met him socially ... Okay thank you Cindy. You’re a really good friend ... OK like twenty minutes. ‘Bye! IN HER SMALL LIVING ROOM -- He comes out of the bathroom. Marianne is now dressed up to go out. She looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. Can I give you a tip?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You mean, like a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (Taking out a ten) No -- I mean -- like, a tip...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s all right. Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, please. I'd feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (Takes the money) OK, thanks a lot. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Good night! And thank you so much. INT. MRS OLSEN’S BATHROOM. DAY. Lee is down on his hand and knees. MRS OLSEN, 40s, ina bathrobe, is very good-looking but bad-tempered and nervo

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: How many times do we have to fix these fucking pipes? Every time I take a shower their entire apartment has a flood. It’s driving me insane.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'll bring the plumber tomorrow but I’d say we’re gonna have to break through the tile and try to isolate the leak, because there was quite a lot of water --

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: But how do you know it’s me? Why is it automatically me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Because if it was coming from higher up you’d have water damage on the ceiling too, and maybe in your wall, and it’s all dry.  Lee looks

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: Great. at the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It might just be the caulking. This whole tub needs to be re-caulked. Did you take a bath or shower in the last couple of hours?

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, it could actually just be that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: OK. And how are you planning to find that out?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well, we could turn on the shower and see if it drips downstairs...

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: You want me to take a shower now?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: You want me to take a shower while you stand there watching, to see if the water drips down into the Friedrich’s apartment?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t really give a fuck what you do, Mrs. Olsen. I just want to find the leak. Mrs Olsen goes white with shock and fury. OK.

dialogues.speaker: MRS OLSEN
dialogues.text: No, you can get out of my apartment and don’t ever come back.

dialogues.speaker: LEE MRS OLSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How dare you fucking talk to me like that? Get the fuck out of my house before I call the police!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You're blockin’ the doorway.  INT. MR EMERY’S OFFICE. NIGHT. The building manager's office. MR EMERY is in his 50s. Le sits in the chair before the crowded desk.

dialogues.speaker: EMERY
dialogues.text: What the fuck’s matter with you? You can’t talk to the tenants like that! Lee shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EMERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, Lee. You do a good job. You're dependable. But I get these complaints all the time. You’re rude, you're unfriendly, you don’t say good mornin’. I mean come on!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Mr Emery, I fix the plumbing. I take out the garbage. I paint their apartments. I do electrical work -- which we both know is against the law. I show up on time, I’m workin’ four buildings and you get all the money. So do whatever you’re gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: EMERY
dialogues.text: Would you be willin’ to apologize to Mrs Olsen?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: EMERY
dialogues.text: All right, all right, I’1l talk to her. Lee gets up to go. INT. A LOUD QUINCY BAR. NIGHT. Lee drinks alone at a small, crowded neighborhood bar. AT THE BAR -- Lee is waiting for service. Someone bumps a CUTE GIRL, 30s, into him. She spills some beer on Lee.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL LEE
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I’m sorry! Did I That’s OK. I’m OK... get you? Yeah. Lemme get a napkin. Lenny, could I get a couple of napkins? (Gives Lee some napkins.) Here you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Well, now I spilled beer all over you, my name’s Sharon.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: And you are...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lee. She gets the message that he is not interested. He pats himself dry, not looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: The bar is far less packed. We see SHARON across the room talking to a girlfriend. At the bar, Lee is drinking alon He’s pretty drunk by now. He is looking at two BUSINESSME 40s. One of them notices and mentions it to the other. Th look at him for a moment then ignore him. He gets up and walks toward them. They are surprised at his approach.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: How you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: How you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good. I’m good. Can I ask you guys, have we met before? The two men look at each other then back at Lee.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think so either.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So you guys don’t know me?

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BUSINESSMAN 2ND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: No... No, Yeah. No. Do we? No.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well then what the fuck are you lookin’ at me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I said why the fuck are you lookin’ at me?

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BUSINESSMAN 2ND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Sir, we really weren't Hey! Take a fuckin’ walk. Hey looking at you -- -- Paul -- No -- don’t apologize to this asshole-- BARTENDER (To LEE) Take a hike! (Hurrying over) Hey, Lee...Lee...! Lee HITS the 2nd Businessman and knocks him into a wall. Several pictures fall and smash on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Oh, goddamnit -- Lee punches the lst Businessman’s nose. He falls back and grabs his face, blood streaming from both nostrils. The 2 Businessman and Lee swipe at each other.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BUSINESSMAN 2ND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: You broke my fuckin’ nose! Goddamn lunatic -- The BARTENDER leaps over the bar and grabs Lee from behin Other guys join in to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER VARIOUS VOICES
dialogues.text: Lee! Lee! Lee! Enough! Break it up! Break it up!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lemme go. I gotta go take a hike. General melee. INT. LEE’S BASEMENT APARTMENT. NIGHT. Lee turns the light on and comes in. He is a little rough up from the fight. At his dresser, Lee pulls on sweatpants and an undershirt There are THREE FRAMED PHOTOS in imitation silver frames standing on the little dresser. We don’t see the photos. Lee sits on the sofa with a beer and turns the TV on to a late-night sports program. Slowly he falls asleep. The ca his hand tips slowly sideways and spills onto the sofa.  EXT. LEE’S STREET. DAY. It’s snowing. Lots of slow, heavy flakes, very pretty. EXT. LEE’S BUILDING -- WINTER. DAY. Lee is shoveling snow. The air is clear and cold. The who street is beautified by the recent snow storm. His iPhone rings. He takes off his gloves. Digs out the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hello ... This is Lee ... Oh... When did that happen? ... Well, how is he? ... OK. Uh...No. Don’t do that. I’1l come up right now ... OK. Thank you. He hangs up and goes inside with the shovel, leaving the before the building only partially cleared and salted dow INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING). DAY. Lee sits behind the wheel, trying to get out of Boston an onto Rt 1. North. He’s talking on his iPhone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (Into his iPhone) Mr Emery, it’s Lee again. I contacted Jose, who says he can cover for me til Friday night at least, and then Gene MacAdavey can take over till I get back. I’1l be in Manchester at least a week or two. I’1l call again when I have more information. Goodbye. He hangs up and drives into increasingly heavy traffic.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. The traffic slows. He becomes increasingly anxious. EXT. RT. 128 -- LEE’S CAR (MOVING). DAY. Lee’s car takes the exit for Beverly. EXT. BEVERLY HOSPITAL. DAY. Lee drives through the grounds of a big modern hospital. knows exactly where he’s going. He parks and gets out. He walks quickly to the main entrance, then breaks into a ru  10. INT. BEVERLY HOSPITAL. DAY. We lead/follow Lee as he walks quickly through the halls toward the ICU, easily navigating the twists and turns fr habit. He goes into the ICU -- INT. ICU -- NURSE’S STATION -- CONTINUOUS. DAY. -- and approaches GEORGE, around 50, a big weatherbeaten and NURSE IRENE, 40s. They both react as Lee approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hiya, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Is he dead? George’s eyes fill with tears. He makes a helpless gestur

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Lee. He passed away about an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. Lee looks at the floor, hands on his hips. Nurse Irene gi his arm an awkward squeeze. Lee stares into the middle distance for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean -- No --

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: George br -- I brought him in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...We were lookin’ at the boat this mornin’, and he just -- I don’t know, he just, like, fell over. I thought he was kiddin’ me at first. Then I called the ambulance ...and uh -- that was it. Lee shakes his head, still staring at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: I‘1l just call Dr Muller and tell him that you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where’s Dr Betheny?
Oh, she’s on maternity leave. Oh here he is. DR MULLER, 40s, has just joined them.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Lee? I’m Dr Muller. We spoke phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: I'm very, very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Hello, George. He shake hands with George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hiya Jim.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: How you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh -- Great! You know.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Well...it’s a very sad day.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. on the George starts to cry. He looks down and wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Where’s my brother?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: He’s downstairs. You can see him if you want.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What happened?  12.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Well, you know his heart was very weak at this point, and it just gave out. If it’s any comfort, I don’t think he suffered very much. I’m sorry you didn’t get here in time, but as I told you on the phone --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Aw, fuck this. (He looks at the floor. Long pause. He looks up.) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's perfectly all right. That’s OK, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Did anybody call my Uncle? DR MULLER and GEORGE glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Their Uncle Donny.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, my Aunt and Uncle. No, Lee -- Lee, no -- Somebody shoulda called them. What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Donny got a job in Minnesota, like --

dialogues.speaker: LEE GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Minnesota? -- awhile ago. Yeah: He got a job with some outfit in Minnetonka, Minnesota, if you can believe that. Joe didn't tell you about that?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can call ‘em if you want, Lee. And tell ‘em what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: OK. Thanks...  13.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell ‘em...Tell ‘em what Oh, no problem -- happened. Tell ‘em I’1l1 call ‘em tonight, probably tomorrow. Talk about arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sure, I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And somebody better call my wife. There is a confused, embarrassed hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Your...

dialogues.speaker: LEE GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ex-wife. Yes. Sorry. You mean Randi? I meant Randi. That's OK -- I already thought of that. I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: OK, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Can I see him now?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lee -- I can wait up here, Lee, in case you need anything.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Dr Muller leads Lee away. George breaks down again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: Would you like a Kleenex?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Yeah.  14. INT. HOSPITAL ELEVATOR. Dr Muller and Lee ride down very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How is Dr Betheny?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Oh, she's doing very well. She just had twin girls.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Irene told me.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Apparently weigh about eleven pounds apiece. So she's gonna have her hands full for a while...I’11 call her this afternoon and tell her what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She was very good to him.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Yes she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE CHANDLER is lying in the hospital bed. There’s a clos resemblance between him and Lee. ELISE, Joe's wife, the same age as Joe, pretty, anxious a high-strung -- stands near to STANLEY CHANDLER -- Lee and Joe's father, 70s. He sits in one chair. LEE sits in anot They are all listening to DR BETHENY, 30s. She is small, intense, very serious and focused and level-headed, but thoroughly well-meaning and decent.

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: The disease is commonly referred to as congestive heart failure --

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Then what are you sayin’ “Oh my God” for?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Because what is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She's tryin’ to explain it to us, honey. I’m sorry, Dr Beth...uh...

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: Betheny:

dialogues.speaker: JOE DR BETHENY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I can never get it Don’t worry about it. Not a right. problem.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: So, you were saying, Dr Beth.

dialogues.speaker: JOE LEE
dialogues.text: It’s Dr Betheny, Dad. Dr Betheny, Daddy, try to get it right..

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: It’s a comedy routine!

dialogues.speaker: JOE STAN
dialogues.text: Would you let her tell it? Elise, please...

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh my God: When am I gonna put one foot right?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Honey, for Christ’s sakes!

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: How about a hint? Stanley takes Elise’s hand and holds onto it.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Elise...Sweetheart...Let’s just let her explain the situation to us...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: What? She's fine. We're all upset. We're all gonna listen, then we're gonna ask everything we wanna ask, and then we’re gonna figure out what do to, together. Right?  16.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: It's a gradual deterioration of the muscles of the heart. It’s usually associated with older people, but in rarer cases it will occur ina younger person. Some people can live as long as fifty or sixty years with just an occasional attack. But most people suffer periodic episodes, like the one you had on Monday, which mimic the symptoms of a heart attack and which further weaken the muscle. They can put you out of commission for a week, two weeks. And you’1l need to be hospitalized so we can monitor your heart, because the risk of cardiac arrest is elevated for a week or two.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (Pats her hand) K..-OK...

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: But in between these episodes, most people feel perfectly healthy and you can basically live a normal life.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So...What do you mean that some people live as long as fifty or sixty years? You mean total? Or from when they're diagnosed with this, or what? And tell me the fuckin’ truth.

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: Total. Everyone is stunned into silence, even Elise. DR BETHENY (CONT’D) For approximately eighty percent of patients your age the most common statistical life expectancy is five years or less. Elise grips Stan’s hand. Lee looks at the floor.  17.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: But the statistics vary widely, and they’re just statistics. You’re not a statistic, you’re just one person, and we don't know what’s going to happen to you yet. But it’s not a good disease.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What’s a good disease?

dialogues.speaker: DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: Poison Ivy.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: (Rising) I do not see where the humor lies in this situation.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Elise, you must calm down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE DR BETHENY
dialogues.text: Honey, please... I’m sorry. I’m really not trying to --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (To Dr Betheny) Don’t -- it’s fine. Elise pulls her hand away from Stan and waves “No” at the

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No. No more -- I’m not gonna --

dialogues.speaker: STAN ELISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elise, let’s get you a glass No m -- No. of water --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Daddy. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (TO LEE)
dialogues.text: Hey, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Yeah, forget it. Forget it like you -- No, you know what? I’m tired of bein’ the bad guy here.

dialogues.speaker: JOE STAN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Who’s in the Nobody th -- fuckin’ hospital?!  18.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Right! So I'll be the bad guy, and you be in the hospital and explain the jokes to your son. I’m goin’ home.

dialogues.speaker: JOE STAN
dialogues.text: You're goin’ home. Sweetheart -- SHE WALKS OUT fast, her heels clicking against the floor.

dialogues.speaker: STAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lemme get her back.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Fuck her.

dialogues.speaker: JOE STAN
dialogues.text: You wanna stop with that Come on with that stuff shit? already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ELEVATOR DOOR OPENS AT LL2. Dr Muller and Lee come ou INT. MORGUE. A SECURITY GUARD opens the door for DR MULLER and LEE.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tony. Lee goes in and looks down at the body. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (Hesitates) OK.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Take your time. Lee moves closer to the body. He touches Joe’s hand. It f dead so he touches his shoulder where there’s a sleeve. H leans over and kisses his cheek. He embraces the body as he can. Dr Muller drops back discreetly. Lee walks out pa Dr Muller. Dr Muller follows.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To the Security Guard) Thanks, Tony.  19. INT. ELEVATOR. Lee and Dr Muller ride up again in silence. INT. BEVERLY HOSPITAL. ICU. FLOOR. DAY -- CONTINUOUS. The ELEVATOR DOOR OPENS. Lee and Dr Muller come out and w to the Nurse’s Station, where IRENE and GEORGE wait.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I gotta get up to Manchester. Nobody told Patrick, right?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: No -- you had asked us to wait for you to get here --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (On “us”) Yes -- Thank you. So...What is the procedure now?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Well -- You should make arrangements with a funeral parlor, and they pretty much take care of everything.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don't know the name of one.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: We can help you with that.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And they come up and get him?

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll make those calls, Lee --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lemme know if you need any OK. And -- OK. Thanks. And -- help with anything. Yeah. Plus I gotta call you about the boat, and the web site. All that shit.  20.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure. I’m around.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: OK. I better get up there before school lets out.

dialogues.speaker: DR MULLER
dialogues.text: You just have to sign for Joe's belongings. Nurse Irene takes Lee around to the nurse’s station so Le can sign for Joe’s belongings.

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN YEARS AGO --
dialogues.text: EXT. THE SEA -- JOE’S BOAT. DAY. Autumn. LEE, JOE and 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK are on JOE’S BOAT The Cape Ann coast is in the distance. The boat is rigged whale-watching and deep sea fishing charters. Lee discree keeps a hand near the rod as 8-Year-Old Patrick trolls. J is at the tiller. He's looking thinner but better.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: Like that?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, only keep your thumb off the line, ‘cause if you get a strike it's gonna slice it right open. And you know what happens then.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: The sharks are gonna smell that blood and rip this boat apart.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: No they won’t. Dad, will they?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. I seen a school of sharks tear a boat to pieces like it was made of cardboard, just ‘cause some kid threw a band-aid in the water.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: No you didn’t.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sometimes the only way to keep ‘em off is to throw the kid directly in the ocean to distract ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: Shut up. Sharks don’t even swim in schools.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Is this kid smart or what?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yep. And a really smart kid is exactly the kind of quality meal a humongous school of sharks is lookin’ for when they’re circlin’ a boat.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Uncle Lee! Shut up! Patrick's REEL starts SPINNING OUT with a thrilling whine

dialogues.speaker: LEE JOE
dialogues.text: Strike! Strike! Look out, look out! Ease up on the drag -- You got a strike! And watch that fuckin’ thumb! Ease up, ease up!

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: (Hits him) No swearing! Patrick loses his balance. Lee catches him and props him

dialogues.speaker: LEE JOE
dialogues.text: Don't hit me -- ! Catch the What are you guys doin’? Hook fish! We're doin’ fine. (To the fish! Get the hook in him Joe) Just drive the boat. before he -- ! I’m drivin’ Patty, pull up sharp! Come the goddamn boat. Get that on, buddy! There you go! (To hook in him! JOE) Mind your business! Lee helps Patrick pull the rod back sharply a few times.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: What kind of fish is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE LEE
dialogues.text: Gotta be a great white, Patty Feels like a great white -- Maybe a barracuda -- shark to me.

dialogues.speaker: 8-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: Shut up!  22. Patrick is ecstatic with nerves and excitement.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT --
dialogues.text: INT./EXT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING)/RT. 128 NORTH. DAY. Lee drives up the highway. EXT. THE OCEAN -- MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA. DAY. FROM THE OCEAN -- We see the wealthy summer resort clingi to the Cape Ann winter coastline. INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING) DAY. Thru the windshield, Lee sees the MANCHESTER EXIT approac He takes the exit. INT./EXT. LEE’S CAR/MANCHESTER. DAY. Lee drives past the old houses of the little town.

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN YEARS AGO --
dialogues.text: INT. LEE’S MANCHESTER HOUSE. DAY. Evening of the same day as the fishing scene. Lee comes i his small house and takes off his wet things. In the livi room, his daughter SUZY, 7, is watching TV. A fire is crackling behind a fire screen. A radio is playing O.S.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi honey! (To the girl) Hi, Suzy. Daddy's home. (Pause) Hi, Suzy. Daddy’s home.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY
dialogues.text: Hi Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetheart. He bends down to kiss her. She hooks her arm around his n and pulls him off balance, her eyes locked on the TV scre suzy LEE (CONT'D) Hug. Jesus Christ, you’re breakin’ my neck.  23. He kisses her and she releases him. nee? RANDI (0.S.) ee?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, hiya! INT. BEDROOM. DAY. RANDI, Lee's wife, 30s, is in bed with a cold. She is tou loving and sarcastic. The room is littered with Kleenex a cold remedies and clothes. KAREN, 5, is playing with colo plastic blocks on the floor. There is a CRIB in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi honey.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: You have a good time?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, really good. Where’s your mother?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: They just left.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Yeah, she really missed you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: There's always next time. Did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. It’s always restful when my mother’s here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. Hi Kary.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Hi Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (Picking her up) Hello sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Put me down.  24.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m puttin’ you down. Relax. He kisses her and starts to put her down. She wriggles an jerks unexpectedly backward. Lee almost loses his grip.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey! Karen...!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (Putting her down) Honey, don’t jerk around like that, I almost dropped you on your head.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm making a hair salon.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? It’s really good. You wanna cut my hair?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It’s just for girls. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I understand. (To Randi) How you feelin’?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Little better.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You sound better.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Did you actually use the fishin’ tackle?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we really did. Patrick got a humongous bluefish. Eighteen pounds.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? That’s awesome!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I never seen anybody so happy in my life. He crosses to her through the tissue-strewn, cluttered ro

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s nice in here. You keep it nice. What a homemaker.  25.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Fuck off. He tries to kiss her. She turns her head.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get away from me. They kiss. She claps his hand onto her breast.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, don't, stop, I'm sick. They kiss some more. She shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, get offa me. Lee goes to the CRIB. Inside is STANLEY, 8 months old, aw and placid, waving his limbs at a multicolored mobile.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi Stanny. How come you’re not cryin’?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Let him alone. He’s been quiet for half an hour. Lee picks the baby up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Half an hour. What is that Oh Lee, please don't pick him about? Take it easy. (To the up! baby) Hiya buddy. You are very handsome. If he’s not makin’ any noise, leave well enough alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: “Leave well enough alone.” That’s what me and Mummy shoulda done instead of gettin’ married.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: (Opens her magazine) Just shut up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: ...-but then you wouldn’t be here. And neither would your sisters. And I could watch the football game in my own livin’ room. That’s right, I could.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself.  Lee kisses the baby and puts him back in the crib.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: See? I didn’t make him cry. ‘Cause I know how to handle him.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: How was Joe?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’s all right. You know? He’s doin’ all right.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: And you didn’t run outta beer? You got through the day OK?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. We were very temperate.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you guys bother gettin’ on the friggin’ boat.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Because we love the sea.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I only had eight beers over a seven hour period. That’s approximately one point four two somethin’ beers per hour.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: No, it’s almost like a normal person stayin’ sober.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I told you I was cuttin’ down. Lee starts to get undressed.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I guess I’m gonna take a shower. Randi, I swear to God. You shoulda seen the look on Patty’s face when he caught that fish. It was like takin’ Suzy on the merry-go-round. It was like -- pure happiness. She smiles at him. Lee crawls across the bed. 26.  27.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Get away. I’m sick. I’m deeply sick. They kiss. Karen plays on the floor. The baby waves his a The TV can be heard from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He’s not at school?

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT --
dialogues.text: EXT./INT. MANCHESTER -- PINE STREET/LEE’S CAR. DAY. Lee drives into town, talking on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I thought school let out at I'm pretty sure he -- three o'clock -- What? I'm I'm pretty sure he woulda -- sorry. My cell phone -- what? That's all right. I’m prett sure he woulda left for hockey practice by now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MANCHESTER ESSEX REGIONAL HIGH SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Over an establishing shot of the big school building we h

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s on the hockey team? INT. VICE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE. DAY -- CONTINUOUS. PAUL, the vice principal, 40, is on the phone. His ASSIST 50s, is on her computer nearby. WE CUT BETWEEN PAUL AND L

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s doin’ real well, too. How’s Joe doin’? He gonna be OK?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He’s fine. Where’s the practice at? The school?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No -- It’s in Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s at the Gloucester -- It’s not at school? What? That’s OK. Can you hear me? I’m sorry -- This phone is -- Yes. We play with the Rockport team. But they’re the lead I understand -- team.  28.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, thanks, Paul. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Give Joe my regards, will you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I will. INT. VICE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE -- CONTINUOUS. PAUL hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Joe Chandler's in the hospital again.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh...Oh my gosh. That poor man has had more trouble...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Who was on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That was Lee Chandler.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Lee Chandler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The very one. INT./EXT. LEE’S CAR/RT 128 NORTH. DAY. Lee drives. The SIGN for GLOUCESTER and ROCKPORT is up ah INT. GLOUCESTER MIDDLE SCHOOL -- HOCKEY RINK. DAY. The Rockport/Manchester team is having practice. PATRICK on the ice. He is just 16, skinny, athletic, long-haired. is bright, practical, pugnacious. The HOCKEY COACH, 40s, shouting instructions. PATRICK checks another KID against boards. They start fighting. They’re evenly matched but Patrick is kind of wild. The COACH yanks Patrick off the other kid.  29.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: OK, break it up! Break it up! You! Chandler! One more time and you are OUT. Understand me? Patrick sees LEE in the stands, over the coach’s shoulder

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Aw, fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: What’s that, Chandler?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Aw, fuck my fuckin’ ass.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: OK, you are out! You're benched!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (To himself, skating away) Ask me if I give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: What’s that? What’s the matter? Patrick skates over to Lee. The Coach sees Lee and hesita A small scrappy kid named JOEL skates up, followed by CJ, big handsome athletic kid. These are Patrick’s friends.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: That’s his uncle. Co His dad must be in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: Whose dad? Chandler’s? Co JOEL He’s got congestive heart ...-He only comes up when Mr failure. Patrick’s dad, I Chandler’s in the hospital. mean. Not Patrick. Some other kids skate up and are watching Patrick and LEE

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: That’s Lee Chandler? The Lee Chandler? Co Yeah, but you know that stuff about him’s bullshit, Mr Howard.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, that story’s bullshit.  30.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: You guys wanna watch the language? JOEL Co Sorry. Sorry. Across the rink, Lee is talking to Patrick. Patrick is kicking up little shards of ice with his skate. The Coach notices that all the kids have stopped to watch.

dialogues.speaker: HOCKEY COACH
dialogues.text: OK, Everybody wanna mind their own business? Five minute break. That means five! The kids break up, marginally. The Coach skates over to L and Patrick. They talk briefly. The Coach puts a well-mea but sentimental hand on Patrick’s shoulder. Lee goes back the aisle. CJ and Joel skate over to Patrick. He tells them. They re sincerely and with sympathy. They squeeze his shoulder, t each hug him. All the kids are watching again by now. HOCKEY COACH (CONT’D) OK, show’s over! Let’s line it up again! Come on, line up! The kids start skating around, lining up at the blue line Patrick breaks away and skates toward the exit by himself INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING). DUSK. The winter sun is getting low. Patrick sports a semi-grun garage-band look. Longish greasy hair, Army jacket, black shirt with some design on it, cargo pants maybe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh well. They pass a sign for MANCHESTER, BEVERLY and NORTH SALEM.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I gotta go back to the hospital and sign some papers. Do you wanna see him?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Him who? See who?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Your dad. Do you wanna look at him?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What does he look like?  31.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He looks like he's dead. (Pause) I mean, he doesn't look like he's asleep, or anything like that. He doesn't look gross...(Pause) You don't have to. I wanted to see him. Maybe you don't want that image in your memory. I don't know. It's up to you. Patrick is silent. INT/EXT. LEE’S CAR/HOSPITAL PARKING LOT. DUSK. Lee pulls into a parking space. He looks at Patrick, who looking slightly queasy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What do you think? Should I take you home? Do you want me to decide?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Let's just go. At the same instant Patrick opens his door to step out an Lee starts DRIVING. He slams on the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I just said let’s go inside!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, you just said “Let’s just go!” LEE (CONT’D) PATRICK And then you get out of the Yeah, I meant let’s go car without telling me? inside. I meant let’s just go What the fuck’s the matter look at him! with you? OK, OK! What’s your problem? I coulda ripped your fuckin’ leg off, that’s my problem. OK! I’m sorry I misused the English language! They get out of the car, both more subdued. PATRICK (CONT’D) I’m sorry, Uncle Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry too. I just got scared.  32. INT. HOSPITAL MORGUE. NURSE IRENE and LEE stand by while Patrick looks at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: OK. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE IRENE
dialogues.text: Of course... Patrick walks away. Lee and Dr Muller follow. INT/EXT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING)/R 128 NORTH. DUSK/NIGHT. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well, that was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I guess I gave you bad advice.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No...I decided... EXT. THE SEA. DUSK/NIGHT. WIDE ON THE COAST: A few headlights move through in the d town. EXT. MANCHESTER -- STREETS. NIGHT. Lee’s car drives through the narrow hilly streets. INT. LEE’S CAR. (MOVING) DUSK/NIGHT. SIMULTANEOUS. They drive in silence. Lee slows the car to a halt. The narrow street is blocked by an SUV by a big house. A visi family is saying goodnight to a family in front of the ho

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Come on...(Pause) Come on, come on! He HONKS the HORN LOUD, TWICE. Everybody looks at him. Th CAR DAD comes around to the driver's side of the SUV...

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: Sorry! Sorry! Come on, guys...! The others continue saying goodbye and chatting. Lee HONK the HORN several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either get in the car or move it in the driveway! 33.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you? The Car Dad turns around. The House Dad takes a step forw

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: What’s your problem, pal?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me to relax. You're sitting in the middle of the street. (HONKS)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Would you stop it, Uncle Lee? It's the Galvins and the Doherties! Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh. It is?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes! What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (Waving out the window) Hiya Mr Doherty. It’s Patrick Chandler. Hi Mrs Doherty...Mr Doherty! It’s OK: It’s Patrick Chandler! Yeah, it’s just me. Hi. Sorry about that. We’re just late. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hi Mrs. Galvin. Hiya Mrs. Doherty. I’m OK. How are you? Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: (Squinting) Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: CAR MOM
dialogues.text: We're leavin’, we're leavin’! Sorry! (Kisses House Mom) I’1l call you tomorrow. (To LEE) OK, OK, OK! In the car, kids!

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: You wanna play tough guy with me in front of all my kids?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE MOM
dialogues.text: Goodnight kids! Come over any time!

dialogues.speaker: CAR KIDS
dialogues.text: Goodbye! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: CAR MOM
dialogues.text: Tommy, come on.

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: Patrick? Is that you? Well, for Christ’s sakes! Where’s the fire?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE MOM
dialogues.text: Hello, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE DAD
dialogues.text: Patrick? Jesus, what’s the ruckus all about? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: CAR MOM
dialogues.text: Oh for goodness sake...!  34.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE
dialogues.text: It’s just my Uncle Lee. It’s It’s Lee Chandler. my uncle.

dialogues.speaker: CAR DAD
dialogues.text: Lee? There is instant awkwardness between them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE CAR DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi Tom. Sorry -- I’m sorry: I Oh. Hey, Lee...What’s all t didn’t know you... rumpus for? CAR MOM Well, keep your shirt on Hello, Patrick. on...! I’m movin’.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs Galvin. Lee calls to the House Dad through Patrick’s open window.

dialogues.speaker: LEE HOUSE KIDS
dialogues.text: Hello, Jeff. Hello, Arlene. Hi, Patrick! Hey, Patrick! HOUSE DAD (Coldly) PATRICK Hey, Lee. Hey guys. How’s it goin’? CU: HOUSE MOM. She pointedly refuses to answer Lee at all

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: .«..Sorry about the ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE MOM
dialogues.text: Patrick, how’s your dad?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He’s fine. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. The car stops in front of the GARAGE of a small well-kept clapboard house with lots of bare trees and shrubs around

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You gotta hit the bleeper.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t have the bleeper.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'll do it. There’s a code. Patrick gets out and goes to open the garage door manuall  35. INT. JOE'S HOUSE. NIGHT. Lee and Patrick come in and turn on the lights. The house just as it was that morning. The Boston Globe sports sect is spread on the sofa. One of Joe’s plaid shirts is drape over the back of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Is it OK if some of my friends come over? I told ‘em I would call ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Can we get some pizza? There’s nothing to eat here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. (Takes out his iPhone) What kind do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Any kind is fine. Thank you. Lee takes out his phone. Patrick starts to text his frien INT. JOE'S HOUSE -- LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick, Joel and CJ and SILVIE, who seems to be Patrick' girlfriend, are all sitting around in the living room. Th are a bit awkward but well-meaning -- except Silvie, who over-relaxed and too touchy-feely with Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIE
dialogues.text: At least he didn’t suffer. It’s worse for the family, but it’s better for the person. Co Well, he was a fuckin’ great guy, Patrick, I'll tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: That’s for sure. Co I remember one time he took us all out in the boat? Like in sixth grade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that. I remember. And he says -- The boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he made us wear life preservers? And I was like, “What's the difference, Mr Chandler? Boat sinks in this weather we’re dead anyway.” And he says “The life jacket’s to make it easier on the sharks when you go over.” Yeah, he really liked those shark jokes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: He was funny, boy.

But Randi doesn’t like the central heat because it dries her out her sinuses, and she gets these headaches. So I went downstairs and built a fire in the fireplace, and I sit down to watch TV, except there’s no more beer. And I’m still jumpin’ like a jackrabbit. So I put a couple big logs on the fire so the house would warm up when I was gone, and I went to the mini- mart...It’s about a fifteen minute walk both ways. But I didn’t wanna drive cause I was really wasted. And I’m halfway there, and I remember I didn’t put the screen back on the fireplace. But I figure it’s probably OK. So I kept going to the store. And that’s it. One of the logs musta rolled out on the floor when I was gone. The girls were all upstairs... And that’s it. The firemen got Randi out. She was passed out downstairs.
