dialogues.text: Lee comes in and takes off his dark jacket and gets some chicken from the fridge. Patrick comes in, iPhone in hand

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hey, is it OK if I ask Silvie to stay over?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t want her in the house right now.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Why not? you don’t have to talk to her...  73.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t like her. You can go to her house or call one of your friends. That’s it. Patrick is stunned. INT. GUEST/LEE’S ROOM. NIGHT. Lee gets ready for bed. We hear PATRICK in the hall 0O.c.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Would your mom be cool if I came there? ... I have no idea. LATER -- Patrick KNOCKS and comes in. PATRICK (CONT’D) Well, I can’t go there either.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: So...Are you gonna stay in here...?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well -- Yeah. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you’d want to stay in Dad’s room.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why? You want me to?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No. It’s just a better room. And he’s not usin’ it...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'll stay in there. We’re not gonna be here that much longer anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m not movin’ to Boston, Uncle Lee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna talk about that right now. OK?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You said he left you money so you could move.  74.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. But that doesn’t mean I Anyway, what's in Boston? can just -- You're a janitor.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You could do that anywhere. There’s toilets and clogged-up drains all over town.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna talk about it! All my friends are here. I’m on the hockey team. I’m on the basketball team. I gotta maintain our boat now. I work You can’t maintain it -- on George's boat two days a week. I got two girlfriends and I’m in a band. You're a janitor in Quincy. What the hell do you care where you live? Lee has no answer. INT. JOE'S BEDROOM -- NIGHT. Lee puts the last of his stuff away. He goes to the windo The wind whistles outside.

dialogues.speaker: 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye Uncle Lee!

dialogues.speaker: FIVE YEARS AGO --
dialogues.text: EXT. JOE’S HOUSE. DAY. A few weeks after the girls’ funeral. Joe waits by Lee’s which is packed with a few boxes and a borrowed suitcase. and 10-YEAR-OLD Patrick come out, carrying cardboard boxe A moment later, Lee slams the trunk. Patrick is inside.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Where you gonna be tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A motel.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What time you gonna call me?  75.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: When I get to the motel.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If I don’t hear from you by nine o'clock I’m gonna call the cops. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patty! Come say goodbye to Uncle Lee!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It is not OK. Patrick! Come say goodbye!

dialogues.speaker: 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Comin’! They wait. Joe hugs Lee. Lee hugs him back woodenly. Then with more feeling. Then he breaks away and gets in the ca

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna see him... He starts the motor. Patrick comes running out of the hou

dialogues.speaker: 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: (Exactly as before) Goodbye Uncle Lee!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So long. He drives off. Joe and Patrick watch him drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, in his sleeping gear, opens the refrigerator, looking for a snack. He opens the overcrowded freezer and some packages of frozen chicken breasts and chopped meat slide out at him. He tries to catch or block them, but mo of them get past him and hit the floor. INT. JOE'S ROOM. NIGHT -- SIMULTANEOUS. At the window, Lee hears the clatter from downstairs.  76. INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS. Patrick looks down at the frozen meat and starts to breat hard. He starts to put them back in but starts to feel si He leans his head against the freezer door then backs awa wiping his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t want it. I don’t want it. LEE comes in. Patrick can’t get ahold of himself.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Patty -- Somethin’s wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I feel really Are you sick? weird! I’m havin’ like a panic attack or something.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Could you get that shit outta the freezer? I feel really weird.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get ridda what? The chicken?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. I don’t know. Should I take you to the hospital? Do you want me to I don’t know! No! call your friends? Patrick runs out of the kitchen. INT. PATRICK’S ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick comes in and slams the door. Pause. Lee KNOCKS 0.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You gonna go to bed?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I don’t think I should let you keep the door shut.  77.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Just go away!

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I will. Just open up the door.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Fuck you. LEE KICKS the DOOR IN. Patrick jumps up from his bed. PATRICK (CONT’D) LEE Jesus! What’s your problem? I said open up the door. Are you havin’ a breakdown? No! No! No! Should I take you to the hospital? No! I’m just freakin’ out. Fine, but I can’t let you freak out with the door shut. Just go away! And if you’re gonna freak out No we don’t - every time you see a frozen chicken I think maybe we should take you the hospital. I don’t know anything about this.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: -- I just don’t like him bein’ in the freezer!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You've expressed that very clearly. I don't like it either. But there’s nothin’ we can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Just get out!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m all right, OK? I just I’m not gonna bother you. wanna be alone. I’m just gonna sit here. You can be alone as soon as you calm down. Patrick turns his face toward the wall. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m calmer now. Would you please get out?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No.  78. Patrick his face turned away. Lee sits there.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE YEARS AGO --
dialogues.text: INT. QUINCY -- LEE’S BASEMENT APARTMENT. DAY. The same basement studio we saw at the beginning, minus m of the furniture. LEE stands watching JOE inspect the roo His affect is flat, colorless. 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK is loo through the window up to the street. People’s feet walk b

dialogues.speaker: 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: Cool!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How much are they payin’ you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Minimum wage plus the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Let’s go get some furniture.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I got furniture.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No you don’t. This doesn’t count as furniture. This is not a room. Let’s go get some furniture.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Get off my back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patty, come on. (To Lee) Let’s go. INT. BOSTON DEPARTMENT STORE. DAY. Joe stands with Lee looking at an armchair. Patrick is spinning around in another one.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You like that one?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Good. Now you got an armchair. Movin’ right along. Let’s go look at lamps.

dialogues.speaker: 10-YEAR-OLD PATRICK
dialogues.text: Uncle Lee, try this one!  79.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patty! Cut the crap. Let’s go get a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I got a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You got a light bulb. Let’s go get a lamp. Patty, come on. INT. LEE’S BASEMENT APARTMENT. NIGHT. Joe finishes tearing the paper off the armchair. The stud now has almost all the same furniture as in the present. stands watching. Patrick is playing a little computer gam

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Better? Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee and Patrick are at the breakfast table. Patrick is ea breakfast. Lee has coffee. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Listen. (Pause) We can stay until your school lets out. That’1ll give me time to set things up in Boston better. You can do some stuff with George in the summer if you want ..-And you don’t get jerked out of your life overnight.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Are you askin’ me or tellin’ me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m tellin’ you it’s the best I can do.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (On “you”) Then what the fuck do you care whether it’s OK with me or not?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s half an hour away! You can come back here any time you want!  80.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: From Quincy? PATRICK (CONT’D) LEE What is that, a joke? Yes! No! Depending on the It’s an hour and a half at traffic. Fifty minutes. least! You gotta include the other cars. But we don’t have to stay there! We could look in You couldn’t get from here to Charlestown, or Everett -- Quincy in half an hour if you flew in a fuckin’ spaceship!

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, fuck it. INT. LEE’S CAR/MANCHESTER ESSEX REGIONAL HIGH SCHOOL. DAY Lee and Patrick pull up in front of school.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I need lunch money. Lee reaches for his wallet. TWO GIRLS rap on the car wind as they pass by on their way into the building.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi, Patrick! Hi, Patrick!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi, Patrick!

dialogues.speaker: 1ST GIRL
dialogues.text: Hey Patrick -- ! Patrick unrolls the window.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So are you goin’ to Godspell?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m thinkin’ about it. 1sT GIRL OK, ‘bye. They move on, giggling. Lee reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Are they your girlfriends too?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: They wish.  81.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Doesn't George pay you a salary for helpin’ with his boat?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I’m savin’ that.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: New motor. Pause. He gives Patrick $20. Patrick gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You goin’ to Godspell? INT. JOE'S BEDROOM. DUSK. Lee puts the THREE FRAMED PHOTOS on the dresser. He goes the window and looks out. He BREAKS the WINDOW with his F Blood wells out of his knuckles immediately. He hurries t the bathroom. The LAND LINE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Come on...! He comes out, wrapping his hand in a towel. The blood soa through quickly. He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? INT. ELISE’S HOUSE. DAY -- CONTINUOUS. Elise, dressed neatly and primly, is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: (Over the phone) Hello, is that Lee? WE CUT BETWEEN ELISE AND LEE. Lee freezes. He does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Over the phone) Hello? Lee? It’s Elise. (Pause) Hello? LEE does not respond. Blood stains the towel on his hand.  82. INT. JOE'S HOUSE -- DINING ROOM. NIGHT. Lee and Patrick sit across from each other at the dinner table, eating. Lee has a bandage on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I cut it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh. For a minute there I didn’t know what happened. INT. JOE'S ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick comes into the room. Lee is VACUUMING up broken g by the window. He has neatly taped a cardboard square ove the broken pane. He sees Patrick and turns off the vacuum throws the last scraps of cardboard and tape into a heavy duty trash bag full of broken glass, cardboard, etc.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Is there some reason why you didn’t tell me my mom tried to call me? Lee stops in his tracks. PATRICK (CONT’D) She wrote me you hung up on her. She’s in Essex. She wants me to see her new house and meet her fiancee. (Pause) What'd you think? She couldn’t get in touch with me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I hung up because I didn’t know what to say to her. And I didn’t tell you ‘cause I didn’t know what to say to you. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You can’t stop me talkin’ to her.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t care what you do. He ties off the garbage bag and goes out. Patrick follows INT. HALLWAY/STAIRS/LIVING ROOM/KITCHEN. CONTINUOUS. They go down the hall, stairs, into the kitchen...  83.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, but you won’t let my girlfriend come over and you hate my mother so much you won’t even tell me that she called. You’d rather drag me back to Quincy and ruin my life than somebody else be my guardian --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: There is nobody else.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I can live in Essex with my mom.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No you can’t.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: But if she's not an alcoholic anymore and she wants me to stay with her, then I can take the bus to my same school and keep all my friends, and the boat, and you can go back to Boston, and you can still -- I don't know: Like, check in on me, or whatever, if you want to...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I hung up on her. I’1l1 call her back, and if she sounds semi-human to me, you can go have lunch with her and her fiancee if you want. I don’t wanna talk about this anymore. Lee goes out the back door with the garbage. EXT. MARINA/WHARF. DAY. Lee stands by as George and Patrick pull away in JOE’S BO Patrick is driving. INT. THE BOAT (MOVING). DAY.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: OK! Soon as we get clear, open it up and we'll see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARINA/WHARF. DAY
dialogues.text: Lee watches them go and then turns and walks away. INT. BOAT YARD -- FRONT OFFICE. DAY. JERRY, 40s, is just coming into the front office as LEE c thru the customer door. Jerry is immediately uncomfortabl

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Hey... Lee...! Well, what do you know?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How you doin’, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Not bad, not too bad. to hear about Joe.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: How’s Patrick doin’?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Good. So what’s goin’

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: .---You know, I’m back and thinking about staying through the summer and was wondering if you had any work? If I could pick up some hours. I was sorry on?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You oughta -- Sure, sure. Walter is down in Boston. He should be back tomorrow if you want to come by or...Give him a call. INT. BACK OFFICE -- SIMULTANEOUS. SUE, 50s, is at a cluttered desk doing paperwork. She hea voices in the front. Stops what she’s doing and listens. WE CUT BACK AND FORTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-Anyway, I’m just lookin’ for anything right now -- Fixit jobs: Boats, engines, -- OK: I’1ll do that. No, I know. I just thought I’d ask.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thanks Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Good to see you. 85.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You oughta -- Sure, sure. You oughta come by tomorrow and talk to Walter...I doubt he’s got anything in February -- Oh, absolutely. They shake hands. After Lee exits, SUE enters the FRONT OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess who just --

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna see him in here again. Lee goes into 1) COASTAL AUTOMOBILE REPAIR. 2) MILNE PLUM & HEATING. 3) HAMMC PAINTING & REMODELING. He talks to managers, EXT. GEORGE'S HOUSE. NIGHT. fills out forms, walks in and out of doors... Lee is picking Patrick up from George’s house. GEORGE and JANINE and their five kids, ages 8-17, wave and shout goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So long...! Patty, I’1l see you Wednesday? So long, Lee!

dialogues.speaker: JANINE
dialogues.text: So long...! INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING). NIGHT. GEORGE’S KIDS Goodbye, Patrick! See ya, Patrick! Bye, Patty! G’bye!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: nBye guys! Yeah, Wednesday! G'bye! Lee and Patrick get in the car and start driving.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How’s the motor?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: George says the piston’s gonna go right through the block any minute now.  86.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately that’s a problem. We can’t afford to keep the boat if we can’t hire somebody to work it, and we can’t get anyone to work it, if it’s got a broken motor.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Let’s take out a loan.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: And pay it back with what?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We hire it out til we pay the loan back, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately for you, I’m responsible for your finances until you're twenty-one, and I’m not comfortable takin’ out enormous loans on your behalf right now.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I have band practice. Can you drive me home to get my stuff and then drive me to Sandy’s house?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sign up for driver's ed?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because Dad made me promise I’m not your chauffeur. not to drive til I was seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK. Then we'll stick with that. EXT. SANDY & JILL’S HOUSE. NIGHT. Lee’s car idles in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You wanna stay for dinner? I think Sandy’s mother likes you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes she does. This could be good for both of us.  87.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’d really rather not.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well, can you at least hang out with her so I can be alone with Sandy for half an hour without her mother knockin’ on the door every twenty seconds?

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, man. All you gotta do is talk to her! Why can’t you help me out a little bit for once instead of draggin’ me to the lawyers and the funeral parlor and the morgue? Anyway she’s really nice!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. SANDY'S HOUSE -- BASEMENT. NIGHT. Patrick is practicing with his band. Sandy on lead vocals the guys singing backup.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: "Tell me why -- Why do you need me? Why do you want me? / Why do you love me?"

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop. Everybody stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Otto, man --

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: What? I'm too slow? Co Too fast.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I'm too fast?  88.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Dude, you're like pullin’ outta the fuckin’ station ahead of me.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you guys! Leave him alone. Co Are you serious about this band or what?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Get off my back. Co All right, everybody just chill here. Let's just go again. Everyone resets.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into microphone) We are Stentorian. INT. JILL’S LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Lee and Jill are alone in the living room. She has a glas wine. He has a beer. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Patrick’s one of my favorite people.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s good. Silence. Jill twists around.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (Calls up the stairs) How’s it goin’ up there, you guys? Silence. Then there is some 0.C. giggling and A DOOR OPEN

dialogues.speaker: SANDY PATRICK
dialogues.text: It’s going fine! Thanks! But Good! Really good! We're we're right in the middle of totally rippin’ through thos something! compound fractions! There is more laughing and the DOOR SHUTS O.C.  89.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: At least we know where they are, right?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s true... INT. SANDY'S ROOM. SIMULTANEOUS. Sandy comes away from the door. They are in their underwe Patrick discards an unused, unrolled condom and GETS UP t get another from his pants, across the darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hold on a sec.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: How many of those you generally gotta go through before you pick a winner?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'd like to see you use one of these goddamn things with all these interruptions -- Ow! He trips over something with a crash.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: What happened? Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I tripped over your fuckin’ doll house.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, did you break it?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m fine though, by the way. Sandy snaps the light on.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. My grandmother gave me that when I was five years old. It was literally her doll house from when she was a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well what’s it doin’ on the fuckin’ floor?  90.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: It’s a doll house! That’s where you play with it!

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sandy? What is going on up there?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Nothing! Patrick stubbed his toe on Mummer’s doll house, but it’s OK!

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sandy, that doll house belonged to my mother!

dialogues.speaker: SANDY JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes I know, Mom! It was just If you’re gonna smash it to an accident. Nobody's pieces I wish you’d let me smashin’ it to pieces! It’s keep it somewhere else! fine!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Jill, I’m OK! My toe’s gonna be OK! INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS. Jill turns back to Lee, smiles and shrugs. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Could I get you another beer, Lee?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m good. Thanks. Jill sips her wine. Lee can’t think of anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me, Lee, one sec?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sure. INT. SANDY'S ROOM. CONTINUOUS. The only light comes from Sandy’s laptop. They’re on the

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Is it on?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: OK. Hurry up.  91. JILL KNOCKS. Patrick and Sandy leap away from each other.

dialogues.speaker: JILL SANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Sandy? I’m sorry...! One second please! (To Patrick) Get outta my way!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Goddamn it! AT THE DOOR, A MOMENT LATER -- Jill is talking to SANDY through a crack in the door. Patrick is pretending to wor the laptop. Sandy and he have pulled on their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry, I know you’re trying to work, but I can’t sit down there much longer.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Why? What’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He won't talk. I’ve been trying to make conversation for half an hour!

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: JILL PATRICK
dialogues.text: I realize I’m not the most What’s the matter? fascinating person in the world, but it’s very, very SANDY strained. Mom...

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: She can't make your Uncle speak.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He likes sports.

dialogues.speaker: JILL SANDY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bust things up, Sports? but how much longer do you think you're gonna be? PATRICK I'm sorry...! Can you talk about sports? Maybe there’s a game on you could watch.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (TO PATRICK)
dialogues.text: Shut up. (To Jill) Mummy, Please.  92. INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING) NIGHT. Lee drives Patrick home.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You were a tremendous help.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask to sit down there.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You can't make small talk like every other grown up in the world? PATRICK (CONT’D) LEE You can't talk about boring No. bullshit for half an hour? “Hey, how about those interest rates?” Hey, I lost Nope. Sorry. my Triple A card?” Like everybody else?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You're a fuckin' asshole. INT. PATRICK’S ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick is having trouble sleeping. EXT/INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING). DAY. Lee is driving Patrick along the road to Essex.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Where did she say she lives? Because there are like no houses here. None. Does she live in a fuckin' sleeping bag?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: 119 Pigeon Hill Street.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pigeon Hill Street? Or Pigeon Pigeon Hill Street. Street! Hill Road? Pigeon Hill Court? This is Pigeon Hill Road. PATRICK (CONT’D) You have no GPS whatsoever?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, I've got a little fuckin' cartoon moving map.  93.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Do you want me to punch it in for you?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, I don't. I've got it. Thank you. (Pause) Okay, listen. Are you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah I’m nervous.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you, a fuckin’ Because -- genius? Skip it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just...If anything gets weird, just text me, and I’ll come and get you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: OK. (Pause) Thank you. EXT. ELISE’S HOUSE. DAY. They pull up to a small neatly kept house and get out. EL opens the front door. She looks starched and brittle.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh. Is that my Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: I’m so happy...! (To Lee) Welcome to my home. INT. ELISE’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. JEFFREY stands waiting as Elise ushers them in. He is in late 40s, slight, well groomed and dressed in conservativ weekend wear. Slacks, loafers, a light-weight sweater. LE glances around the very tidy house. There is a framed pas of Jesus on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Patrick. This is my fella. Jeffrey, this is Patrick...

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: (Shaking hands) Great to finally meet you, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: And this is Lee...

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: (Shaking hands.) Hey, welcome. Jeffrey.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Lee.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Now, Lee, are you sure you won't stay for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m positive. INT. ELISE’S DINING NOOK. DAY. Patrick is at the table. Jeffrey and Elise bring in lunch

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh -- Can I help with anything?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No thanks, honey.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Your job is to relax. OK? That is your A-Number One assignment.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: OK. I’m gonna really apply myself.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: No -- I was just joking.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I know you were. So was I. Elise comes in from the kitchen and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: How we gettin’ along?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to be so polite, you know!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh -- I'm not bein’ polite...

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Did you wanna wash your hands before we eat?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Um -- Yeah. INT. ELISE’S DINING ROOM. DAY. Everyone is seated. Jeffrey is saying grace.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: For what we are about to receive let us give thanks. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE PATRICK
dialogues.text: Amen. Amen They start passing around the lunch.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: It’s OK to say Amen, Patrick...! Nobody's tryin’ to recruit you!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I did say Amen.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: You did? OK. You don't have to...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I know. I just said it really quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Honey, it’s fine. I know -- I’m gonna be a shock to you. In a lotta ways. Hopin’ it’s a good shock...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: What can I get you, Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: I hope everything’s OK...(e.g. the lunch.) 95.  96.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, it looks great. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be so formal...!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY ELISE
dialogues.text: I think Elise’s just -- I know...! I’m just sayin’, this is your home too! I want it to be... It’s different from what you’re PATRICK used to, but...And...I don’t That’s OK... know...!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: What are you studying in school, Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh...well...The usual stuff...

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: You know what? I’m gonna be right back. Anybody need anything from the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY PATRICK
dialogues.text: I think we’re good. No. No, thanks. Thank you. Elise gets up and goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Did you get some string beans?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Oh -- not yet. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: OK. (Pause) Lemme just see what she’s doin’ in there. He goes into the kitchen. Patrick eats. INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING) DUSK. Lee is driving Patrick home. He glances at Patrick. Patri is very glum and unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: So what was she like?  97.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don't know: She was pretty nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What was the guy like?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He was very Christian. LEE PATRICK (CONT’D) You know we're Christian too, Yes, I know that. right? You are aware that Catholics are Christians? Yes I am aware of that. They drive in gloomy silence.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Well...it sounds like she’s doin’ better anyway. She’s not drinkin’. She’s not in the psych ward.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: LEE PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow what? You'll do anything to get ridda me!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That’s not true. Patrick shrugs and starts texting on his iPhone. INT. PATRICK’S ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick sits at his laptop, wet from the shower. He email from JEFFGARNDER7@YAHOO.COM. We see the first and hear JEFFREY’S VOICE at the same time. JEFFREY V.O. “Dear Patrick, I’m writing on to thank you for today. Your visit meant the world to your mom. We are both deeply grateful for the love and trust you’ve shown by offering to rejoin her life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: opens an few lines  98.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I feel it would be unfair to your mom to rush her along the long and challenging road ahead, and so I’m going to ask you to write to me in future to arrange any further visits. I hope you won’t find this to be --” ON PATRICK as he reads on. He DELETES the MESSAGE. INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick is watching an action movie on TV. Lee drifts in.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Where’s your friends tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you call that girl Sandy and see if she’ll come over?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No thanks. Nice try, though. Pause. Lee walks away and goes into -- INT. JOE'S DEN. NIGHT. Lee turns on the light. He walks over to the fancy GUN CA It's got several expensive rifles mounted, and some HANDG Lee gets the key from on top of the case and opens it. He takes out a HANDGUN. Realizes that PATRICK is in the door

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Who are you gonna shoot? You or me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Do you know how much these guns are worth?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: A lot, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Want to try to sell them and put the money toward a new second hand motor for the boat?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: That’s a really good idea.  99. EXT. GUN SHOP. DAY. Through the window we see Lee and Patrick talking to the SHOP OWNER. Joe’s guns are laid out on the counter on a f cloth. The owner is counting out bills for them. EXT. MARINA -- BOAT YARD. DAY. LEE, GEORGE and PATRICK are connecting up the new secondh MOTOR to Joe’s boat.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: This is awesome. EXT. JOE’S BOAT (MOVING) -- AT SEA. DAY. A beautiful day at sea. Patrick is driving the boat, fast SANDY is next to him. LEE is in the back, taking in the a

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: This is awesome!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You wanna drive?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: OK -- So -- The BOAT SWERVES WILDLY as Sandy takes the wheel. PATRICK (CONT’D) SANDY Yeah -- Don’t -- Just (Screams ) straighten her out -- OK. Oh my God! Sorry! She straightens the wheel and speeds up again. EXT. JOE’S DRIVEWAY. DAY. Lee drives Sandy and Patrick into the driveway and stops. Sandy and Patrick get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I gotta run some chores. I'll be back in a couple hours. You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK SANDY
dialogues.text: No thank you. No thanks Mr. Chandler.  100. Lee drives away.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Setup city.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? How's Silvie McGann?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Who?!

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Open the door. INT. PATRICK'S BEDROOM. DAY. SANDY AND PATRICK lie on the bed, her dozing head on his chest. He’s very happy. EXT. WATERFRONT STREET. DAY. Lee is walking toward his car. He slows because he sees R pushing a stroller his way, with a newborn BABY in it. Th baby is almost invisible inside his winter parka. Randi i accompanied by a friend, RACHEL, 40s.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Lee...! Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Um -- Rachel. This is Lee. Lee, Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: (Re: the baby) And this is Dylan. You can’t see him too good.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hey Dylan. Very handsome.  101.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Randi, you want me to get the car and pick you up?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI LEE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure -- That’s OK. I gotta --

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Well, could I -- I’d -- Could we talk a second?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l just pull around -- Just be like two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: OK, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Be right back. Rachel hurries off and turns a corner.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I don’t have anything big to say:

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just -- I know you been That’s OK. around -- Yeah, I just been gettin’ And I thought -- we never -- Patrick settled in. Yeah I know. He seems like he's doin’ pretty well, considering. I mean... I think he is...Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I guess you probably didn’t know I really kept in touch with Joe --

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So it's been kinda weird for No, I knew that -- me, not seeing Patrick since he passed away -- Oh, OK. I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well you can see him. I have no --  102.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Could we ever have lunch?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You mean us? You and me?

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Yeah. I, uh...Because...I said a lotta terrible things to you. But -- I know you never -- Maybe you don't wanna talk to me --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s not that.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: But let me finish. However it -- my heart was broken. It's always gonna be broken. I know your heart is broken too. But I don't have to carry...I said things that I should -- I should fuckin’ burn in hell for what I said. It was just --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I’m just sorry. I love you. Maybe I shouldn’t say that. And I’m sorry --

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t -- You can say it, but -- No, it’s just --I -- I can’t -- I gotta go. We couldn’t have lunch?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: You can’t just die...! But honey, I see you walkin’ around like this and I just wanna tell you -- But Lee, you gotta -- I don't know what! I don't wanna torture you. I just wanna tell you I was wrong. That’s not true! true...! Can't be I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for sayin’ everything --I’m not! But I can’t -- I’m happy for you. And I want...I would want to talk to you -- But I can’t, I can’t... I'm tryin’ to -- You're not. But I got nothin’ to -- Thank you for sayin’ that. But -- There’s nothin’ there ...You don’t understand...  103.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Of course I do!

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I know you understand...But I’ve gotta go -- I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK. I’m sorry. There’s nothin’ I can s -- I gotta go. He moves away. Randi breaks down. INT. WATERFRONT BAR & GRILLE. DAY. CU LEE, very drunk. He is at the counter of a busy local place full of fishermen eating and drinking their lunch. new bunch of guys comes in loudly and boisterously. One o them accidentally clips Lee as the group passes by.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Lee whirls around and sucker punches the Fisherman. He go down hard. His friends immediately grab at Lee en masse.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMEN
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! What’re you doin’? Etc. Lee is pushed into some tables -- The whole place is in a uproar -- He is jumped by several guys. He keeps fighting crazily. Someone tries to pin his arms to stop the fight. Everyone is shouting. GEORGE appears. He uses his size to shove the other guys from Lee.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Break it up! Break it up! It's Lee Chandler. Lee! Let him go, Eddy. He's Joey Chandler's brother. Let him go! Lee. Lee! It's George. Lee. Come on -- (To the guys who beat Lee up) You won. OK? You won the fight. Lee shoves George away and swings at the nearest man. Everybody pounces on him again. Someone hits Lee squarely knocks him down. Now George is fighting everybody. Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee is dazed, lying on the sofa in George's cramped livin room. George watches anxiously as George’s wife Janine finishes washing and bandaging Lee’s banged up face. Geor is a little banged up too.

dialogues.speaker: JANINE
dialogues.text: -..-Should we take him to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Nothin’s broken.

dialogues.speaker: JANINE
dialogues.text: ...What the hell did they hit him with, a fuckin’ baseball bat?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They all just said he started swingin’. Lee wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Where’s Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He’s with the kids. I sent ‘em out for burgers.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Lemme give you some money. Lee sits up painfully and reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lee. Please. It’s my treat. Lee stands up and fumbles for his wallet and drops it on floor. George picks it up and gives it to him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you sit down please, for Christ’s sake?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Lee sits down and breaks into tears.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Come on, buddy. George looks uncomfortable. He looks up toward the kitche Janine comes back in with coffee and sits next to Lee.  105.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That’s OK, buddy. It’s OK...

dialogues.speaker: JANINE
dialogues.text: Lee? Have some coffee. Come on. Drink this... Lee takes the coffee and keeps crying. George and Janine exchange a look. INT. JOE'S HOUSE -- KITCHEN. NIGHT. Patrick comes in, followed by Lee. Lee moves slowly past into the living room. INT. JOE’S ROOM. NIGHT. Patrick walks in and takes a long look at Lee's THREE FRA PHOTOS. INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Lee lies on the sofa nursing a beer, his face swollen and cut. Patrick comes in from the kitchen and hovers.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything, Uncle Lee?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No thanks, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: OK. I’m goin’ to bed.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good night. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE -- DAY. The sun shines over the house, the town, and the water. INT. JOE'S HOUSE -- KITCHEN. DAY. Lee puts some spaghetti sauce in a skillet and turns the flame on.  106. INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY. Lee is asleep on the sofa with a beer while the TV plays. LITTLE HAND tugs at his SLEEVE.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Daddy? He turns his head and sees without surprise his DAUGHTERS seated next to him in their nightgowns. The BABY is in a playpen on the floor. SUZY, 7, is pulling his sleeve. Lee smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yes, honey?

dialogues.speaker: SUZY
dialogues.text: Can't you see we're burning?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No, honey...You’re not burning. LEE WAKES UP -- There’s SMOKE coming from the KITCHEN. INT. KITCHEN. DAY. The blackened skillet is SMOKING. Lee comes in and puts i under the water in the sink. It hisses and steams.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uncle Lee! What the hell’s that smell?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I just burnt the sauce! Everything's OK! He grips the sink and tries to recover from his dream. INT. LEE’S CAR (MOVING) NIGHT. Lee drives up George and Janine’s street. INT. GEORGE’S HOUSE. DAY. PUSH IN: (MOS) LEE is seated at the dining table talking seriously with GEORGE and JANINE. It has the air of a conference.  INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Lee and Patrick eat dinner.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I got a job in Boston. It starts in July.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Custodian, handyman...But just two buildings this time.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: And what delightful Boston neighborhood have you selected for us to live in?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to move to Boston. I’m gonna be in Charlestown and George is gonna take you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I talked to them last week. I explained the situation to them. Georgie Junior’s goin’ to school this fall. Jimmy graduates next year. We’ll have to rent out this house. You can move back in when you turn eighteen. When you turn twenty-one, you’re allowed to sell it or stay in it, or whatever you want. Definitely have to hire the boat out when the summer’s over -- just like we talked about. I thought when you get your license, we can figure that one out as we go. I'm still the trustee, but all the financial stuff Joe set up for me is gonna get transferred over to George. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So everything’ll be the same, except you don’t have to move.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: But...like, are they gonna be my guardians? Or do you still --

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: They’re gonna adopt you. (Pause) Anyway, that's how I set it up. If you want. It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So are you gonna just You don’t have to do it. No. disappear? No. I just set it up so you can stay here. They’re really glad to have you. They love you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I know. I mean, they’re great...But why can’t you stay? Patty starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Come on, Patty...I can’t beat it. (Pause) I can’t beat it. I’m sorry. Patrick wipes his eyes. Lee comes over and hugs him. EXT. MANCHESTER STREET/ROSEDALE CEMETERY. DAY. Patrick walks along the street. The TREES he passes have or BLOSSOMS. It’s early SPRING. He snaps a dead branch of tree. He runs it across a fence as he walks. We REVEAL th he is headed for the cemetery gate. He goes into the cemetery. He pokes his stick into the ground to see if it’s softene up. It has. He digs up some clods. He walks away. EXT. AN OLD MANCHESTER HOUSE. DAY. A MILNE PLUMBING & HEATING VAN is parked in the driveway. INT. BASEMENT. DAY. Lee is kneeling on the floor in coveralls, working on the water heater. The HOMEOWNER, in his 80s, stands by watchi  109.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think you’re gonna be OK.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: Are you one of Stan Chandler’s boys?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m Lee.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: I used to play a little chess with your father a long time ago. He was a heck of a chess player.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That's him.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: He's not still living, is he?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: And one of the sons passed away recently I heard.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Joe. My brother.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: That's right. Very personable man.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: My father passed away in 1959. A young man. Worked on a tuna boat. Went out one morning, little bit of weather, nothing dramatic...And he never returned. No signal. No Mayday. No one ever knew what happened. Lee continues to work on the heater. EXT. LAWYER'S OFFICE WINDOW. DAY. Past the BLOSSOMS on the tree outside Wes’ window, we see GEORGE, LEE and WES, signing documents.  110. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE. DAY. There is a “FOR RENT BY OWNER” SIGN outside the house. Le car is in the yard. Also Patrick’s bicycle. EXT. CEMETERY. DAY. (MOS) Joe’s burial service. PATRICK, LEE, GEORGE and JANI all stand in a row at the front. RANDI holds a CRYING BAB She gives him to JOSH, who steps away. CU: CHANDLER TOMBSTONE. Engraved are the names of Lee's parents and now Joe. EXT. WIDE SHOT OF THE TOWN. DAY. A beautiful early spring day. Lots of boats in the water. EXT. MANCHESTER STREET -- CORNER GROCERY STORE. DAY. Lee and Patrick walk up the street, still in their funera clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get some ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Can I have some money?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lee gives him a ten-dollar bill. Patrick goes inside. Lee picks up an old rubber ball from the ground and bounces i and down. Patrick comes out with an ice cream bar. EXT. MANCHESTER STREET. DAY. Lee and Patrick trudge up a steeply inclined street. Lee occasionally bounces the ball.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: So...When am I supposed to move in with Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: July. I don’t even have a place to live yet.  111.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Don’t they give you an apartment?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I was gonna try to get a place with an extra room. Or room for like a pullout sofa.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: In case you wanna visit sometime. Or if you’re lookin’ at colleges in Boston or somethin’ and you wanna stay overnight...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m not goin’ to college.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: All right, well then I'll have an extra room for all my shit. Do we have to talk about this now?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Nope. He tosses away his ice cream stick. After a minute Lee wipes his eyes. He bounces the ball an tosses it to Patrick. It goes wide and bounces crazily. PATRICK (CONT’D) Great throw.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just let it go. Patrick runs to gets the ball. They continue to walk up t hill, bouncing the ball across the street to each other a chasing it when it rolls back down the hill. EXT. WIDE SHOT OF THE TOWN -- JOE’S BOAT. DAY. Lee and Patrick head out to fish. Patrick drives the boat Lee sets up the fishing gear. A FEW MOMENTS LATER -- Lee and Patrick are seated, fishin off the back of the boat. They talk quietly. Lee looks a little better than we’ve seen him. He squints at the sea the wide open sky. FADE OUT.  112.
